data.title: Could Mason Street bridge be reconstructed? Green Bay, DOT look at long-term options. Here's what to know
data.meta_description: Should state engineers rebuild Green Bay's Mason Street bridge in a different format, height, or should state just keep patching what it can?
data.text:
GREEN BAY - Wisconsin Department of Transportation officials Tuesday evening outlined plans to improve the Mason Street lift bridge and then reconstruct or replace the span across the Fox River over the next 10 years.

About 30 citizens, several business people, and a City Council member representing some of the area served by the bridge, attended Tuesday's forum at Washington Middle School. At the event, DOT began asking for public input on the project; two DOT officials and a consultant spoke to the public briefly about plans.

The DOT has information posted about the project, but has yet to post a cost figure.

Here is what to know about the projects, according to Tuesday's forum and the DOT:

Why does the Mason Street bridge matter to Green Bay?

The Mason Street bridge, formally known as the Donald A. Tilleman Bridge, carries State 54/Mason Street traffic across the Fox River, serving 34,200 vehicles on an average day. It's one of three bridges across the Fox River in downtown Green Bay.

The state Department of Transportation has jurisdiction of the bridge because it is also a state highway.

The current four-lane bridge was built in 1973.

What does the project call for?

The rehabilitation project would begin in 2026 and focus on the lift span on the bridge, which raises for ship traffic on the river.

How much improvement is done to the existing bridge will be determined by the amount of replacement work DOT chooses to do.

"We probably won't sandblast and paint the bridge, if we're going to lower the height of the bridge to (near) ground level," said Joshua Lang, another project manager who spoke Tuesday.

The replacement/reconstruction phase would affect the entire span from 12th Street on the west side to Webster Avenue on the east side. Work on there would not begin until about 2031 or 2032.

If the bridge is replaced, the DOT might choose to adjust the height of the span, perhaps taking it from its current height to something closer to ground level, said Bryan D. Lipke, one of the project managers.

What are the possible outcomes of the Mason Street bridge reconstruction/placement project?

No change: The span is built at essentially the same height, and with essentially the same ramp system.

Lowering the bridge: DOT builds the new bridge closer to street level.

Combination: Build a bridge that combines multiple elements of the two approaches.

What's the expected timing of the work?

The DOT began studying the project this year. DOT expects to be able to address the amount of repair to be done versus the amount of pure construction after 2026. Building would begin in 2031.

Whatâ€™s driving the change?

The main reasons for the projects:

Heavy use and winters of icy/snowy weather create a need for frequent repairs.

Some drivers complain about the long on/off ramps and/or the danger and lack of room to merge on the ramp from South Ashland Avenue to eastbound Mason Street.

Others, including City Council member Brian Johnson, want a bridge that's not elevated. They say it will incorporate more easily with the neighborhoods it serves. Green Bay school officials complain that the current bridge makes it difficult for Howe Elementary School students who walk south of the building.

Where can I find detailed information online?

The DOT has two pages for the project:

The Mason Street bridge rehabilitation project can be found online at https://wisconsindot.gov/Pages/projects/by-region/ne/masonbrrehab/default.aspx

The replacement/reconstruction project can be found online at https://wisconsindot.gov/Pages/projects/by-region/ne/masonstudy32/default.aspx

What if I want to add my voice?

To comment on the rehabilitation project:

Email Joshua.Lang@dot.wi.gov.

Call Lang at 920-492-4141

You can also download a comment form.

For the replacement/reconstruction project:

Email Bryan.Lipke@dot.wi.gov

Call Lipke at 920-492-5703

Or you can also comment online.

Will there be more public meetings?

Yes, the DOT plans two more public meetings, with the next planned for fall 2024.

Email Doug Schneider at DSchneid@Gannett.com, call him at (920) 599-0809 and follow him on X (formerly Twitter) @PGDougSchneider
